name: MCP
summary: Clean client-server design with clear primitives. Developers explicitly opt in, understand the contract, and can swap implementations. But its dominance risks becoming the 'only game in town' — a gentle lock-in through ubiquity rather than coercion.

feedbackLoop.note: Clear request/response. Errors are visible and debuggable via JSON-RPC.

edgeCases.note: Four clean primitives (Resources, Tools, Prompts, Sampling). Happy path is obvious.

ambiguity.note: Deterministic tool invocation. Same inputs → same routing.

redundancy.note: Overlaps with A2A's tool-calling features and ACP's agent invocation.

nesting.note: Flat architecture. No recursive protocol chains.

exitCost.note: 100K+ stars, deep ecosystem lock-in. Switching is technically easy but socially expensive — the 'QWERTY problem'.

identityPenetration.note: Developers increasingly identify as 'MCP-first' builders. The protocol is becoming a tribal marker.

agencyPreservation.note: Participants retain full control over which tools to expose and how.

controlInvisibility.note: MCP's constraints (what can/can't be a tool) shape agent design invisibly — you build what MCP makes easy.

crisisMindset.note: No urgency narrative. Adoption is driven by utility, not fear of being left behind.
